related_facts.fact_group_content: Singapore will reduce emissions to around 60MtCO2e in 2030.
The mean sea level around Singapore is increasing at a rate of around 3.5mm per year from 1993 to 2021.
Annual rainfall total for Singapore has been increasing at a rate of 83 mm per decade from 1980 to 2022.
Much of Singapore lies only 15 m above the Singapore Height Datum.
About 30 per cent of Singapore is less than 5 m above the Singapore Height Datum.
Singapore imports more than 90 per cent of its food.
Lake Victoria’s water levels rose by more than 3 feet due to a pluvial starting in 2019.

clusters.title: Singapore Vulnerability
clusters.description: Singapore is experiencing significant environmental changes, including rising sea levels and increased rainfall, which are indicative of broader climate impacts. The mean sea level around Singapore has been rising steadily, while annual rainfall has also shown an upward trend. These changes pose challenges for a country where a significant portion of the land is low-lying, increasing vulnerability to flooding and other climate-related risks.

clusters.title: Emission Dominance
clusters.description: Carbon dioxide is the predominant greenhouse gas, constituting 75% of climate-warming emissions, while methane, though only 16% of emissions, is 25 times more potent. China is a major contributor, responsible for 26% of global CO2 emissions, whereas the United States, with 4% of the world's population, accounts for 13% of these emissions.
